image.altText: Close up of a hand typing on a keyboard in a dark room

items.synopsis: The Cancer Council, Canteen and Fred Hollows Foundation have confirmed donor information has been published on the dark web after a telemarketer was hacked.

title.children: Cybercriminals publish personal details of thousands of donors to Australian charities on the dark web

image.altText: Hands holding 50, 20 and 10-dollar Australian banknotes fanned out

items.synopsis: Phasing out cash has serious implications for privacy, safety and financial exclusion among marginalised communities.

title.children: Australia's transition to a cashless society is underway — but not everyone wins when we get rid of cash

image.altText: A collection a photos of pregnant women and newborn babies.

items.synopsis: Telehealth is revolutionising medicine in remote areas, but one obstetrician says entrusting the delivery of a baby to "pure luck" in Australia during 2023 "isn't good enough".

title.children: No privacy, no pain relief and no specialist: Mothers traumatised by unplanned telehealth births

image.altText: A man sitting at a desk with his hands clasped together

items.synopsis: The Russian president is facing a potential showdown with Western leaders at next month's G20 summit in India, but an international arrest warrant looms large over any of his travel plans.

title.children: Why Vladimir Putin has a 'huge headache' coming next month

image.altText: John Farnham.

items.synopsis: John Farnham says he a grateful and happy man as he marks the one-year anniversary of a 12-hour surgery to remove a cancerous tumour from his mouth.

title.children: 'Luckiest man alive': Music legend John Farnham gives health update

image.altText: a caravan on a bush block

items.synopsis: Today Janet and others will share their stories at a public hearing in Brisbane into the worsening rental crisis in Australia.

title.children: Janet shares a caravan without a toilet or hot water. She hasn't had a proper home in more than two years

image.altText: Students in a classroom.

items.synopsis: One in three school students throughout Australia are not meeting minimum numeracy and literacy expectations, and one in 10 are so far behind they need additional support, new NAPLAN data shows.

title.children: Results from a brand new NAPLAN system are in — but the report card shows some familiar trends

image.altText: A cable car which has come partially off it's cable in Pakistan.

items.synopsis: For those living in Pakistan's remote and mountainous regions, local cable cars are an important connection between communities where roads are absent.

title.children: Pakistan's makeshift cable cars are a risky necessity for many

image.altText: People watch as an army soldier slings down from a helicopter among mountains.

items.synopsis: All eight people, seven of them children, have been rescued after being left dangling in a Pakistan cable car 275 metres above a ravine for more than 14 hours.

title.children: 'Safely rescued': Pakistan's PM rejoices as 7 children and teacher saved from dangling cable car

image.altText: Wendy Farmer stands in front of her electric vehicle which is parked in her driveway in Gippsland.

items.synopsis: One regional electric vehicle owner says it takes "planning" to reduce range anxiety, while another isn't quite ready to make the long-distance leap.

title.children: Range anxiety should no longer be a problem — so why aren't more people buying EVs in the regions?

image.altText: Donald Trump, wearing a navy suit, holds his red tie down to stop it flapping as he descends airplane stairs

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: First of Trump's co-accused surrenders in Georgia: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Minister for Education Jason Clare is speaking with ABC News Breakfast about new NAPLAN data revealing one in three students aren't meeting numeracy and literacy expectations. About a third of Indigenous students 'need additional support'. "I think this report makes that blisseringly clear,' he says. "We've got a good education but it can be better and it can be fairer." Clare says one of the issues is that not all schools in the country are equally funded and work needs to be done across all states and territories to fix the gap. Changes have also been announced to better train teachers. "We announced serious reforms a couple of weeks ago to make sure we teach students the fundamentals at university but also improve their practical experience when they're a student," he says. "Unless we do, that teachers are notgoing to be ready on day one. " A report will be presented to the federal government in October which will make recommendations for national school reform to be put in place next year .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Education Minister says NAPLAN report shows serious education reform is needed

props.alt: A man in a suit and tie close up in a news breakfast interview

children.content: The Minister for Education Jason Clare is speaking with ABC News Breakfast about new NAPLAN data revealing one in three students
aren't meeting numeracy and literacy expectations.
About a third of Indigenous students 'need additional support'.
"I think this report makes that blisseringly clear,' he says.
"We've got a good education but it can be better and it can be fairer."
Clare says one of the issues is that not all schools in the country are equally funded and work needs to be done across all states and territories to fix the gap.
Changes have also been announced to better train teachers.
"We announced serious reforms a couple of weeks ago to make sure we teach students the fundamentals at university but also improve their practical experience when they're a student," he says.
"Unless we do, that teachers are notgoing to be ready on day one. "
A report will be presented to the federal government in October which will make recommendations for national school reform to be put in place
next year

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: John Farnham has described himself as "the luckiest man alive" in a health update 12 months after he underwent marathon surgery in Melbourne. The 74-year-old singer released a statement to mark the anniversary of the surgery to remove a cancerous tumour from his mouth. "It's been a year since my first surgery and to be honest I've lost count as to how many other procedures there's been since then. I'm sure someone's kept track of them all — let's just say, there's been a few," he said. "But, I'm home now and I'm a very grateful and happy man." "It's only now that I can start to appreciate and comprehend, for myself, how many messages of love and support have been sent to me over the past year," he said. "I don't know what to say, other than thank you so very much. It honestly means the world to me." You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: John Farnham given the 'all clear' by doctors one year after cancer surgery

featuredLink.title: 'Luckiest man alive': Music legend John Farnham gives health update

children.content: John Farnham has described himself as "the luckiest man alive" in a health update 12 months after he underwent marathon surgery in Melbourne.
The 74-year-old singer released a statement to mark the anniversary of the surgery to remove a cancerous tumour from his mouth.

"It's been a year since my first surgery and to be honest I've lost count as to how many other procedures there's been since then. I'm sure someone's kept track of them all — let's just say, there's been a few," he said.
"But, I'm home now and I'm a very grateful and happy man."
"It's only now that I can start to appreciate and comprehend, for myself, how many messages of love and support have been sent to me over the past year," he said.
"I don't know what to say, other than thank you so very much. It honestly means the world to me."
You can keep reading this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Albanian police have shown footage of the arrest of a man suspected of arson, as authorities continue to battle a major wildfire near the town of Lac. Security camera footage released by police, from the southern town of Berat, shows two men starting a fire. They have also been identified and arrested. "The fire has reached a massive area of pine trees near the town of Lac and this is one of the worst wildfires this year," Interior Minister Taulant Balla said on social media. Local media showed video of an army helicopter pouring water in the area as a flames could be seen close to houses. Defence Minister Niko Peleshi says 50 soldiers were deployed but stopping the fire remained a challenge due to difficult terrain. In July alone, Albania identified and charged 14 people with starting wildfires, which is punishable with up to 15 years in jail. Wildfires are also raging in Greece, Spain, Italy and Portugal, as the region suffers hot, dry and windy conditions that scientists have linked to climate change.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Accused arsonists arrested for allegedly setting wildfires in Albania

props.alt: a man in the silhouette of the sun in Albania wildfire

children.content: (Reuters: Florian Goga)

Local media showed video of an army helicopter pouring water in the area as a flames could be seen close to houses.

image.altText: A woman standing inside an office and looking serious while holding several thick documents.

image.altText: A composite photo zooming in on a small, white fish with hands.

image.altText: A woman with bold glasses sits at a table.

items.synopsis: The federal government says the "door is open" to sign its $13-billion Murray-Darling Basin Plan, but there's no indication so far Victoria wants to walk through.

title.children: Unity in Murray-Darling Basin fractures as Vic refuses to sign onto new plan

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: Grocery giant Woolworths is set to report its annual earnings, and Wall Street ends mixed as investors worry the US central bank will keep interest rates higher for longer. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Woolworths to report annual profit, US stocks mixed as interest rate fears weigh on sentiment

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lower commodity prices have hit the earnings of mining giant BHP. Yesterday it posted its lowest profit in three years, down 58 per cent to $US12.9 billion for 2023. Despite the slowdown in China, BHP still sees iron ore trading between $US80 to $US100 a tonne. Kirsten Aiken spoke to BHP chief financial officer David Lamond on The Business.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China's property crisis to test demand for Australian iron ore

featuredLink.title: China's property crisis to test demand for Aussie iron ore

children.content: Lower commodity prices have hit the earnings of mining giant BHP.
Yesterday it posted its lowest profit in three years, down 58 per cent to $US12.9 billion for 2023.
Despite the slowdown in China, BHP still sees iron ore trading between $US80 to $US100 a tonne.
Kirsten Aiken spoke to BHP chief financial officer David Lamond on The Business.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's markets blog. Investors are cautious on Wall Street ahead of a major speech by US central bank chairman Jerome Powell in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, on Friday. They are worried that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again because of the resilient US economy. Benchmark Treasury yields climbed to near a 16-year high on the concerns. Nvidia shares reached a record high of $US481.87 ahead of the chipmaker's profit results. The S & P 500 fell 0.3 per cent, but the Nasdaq edged higher. Financial stocks fell after credit ratings agency S & P downgraded the credit ratings of multiple US regional banks. Coming up today, Woolworths will release its annual profit, which will give us more insight into the impact of the high cost of living on consumers. Other profit results out today include Domino's Pizza and oil and gas producer Santos. Join us for all your markets news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks end mixed as rates fear weighs

children.content: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's markets blog.
Investors are cautious on Wall Street ahead of a major speech by US central bank chairman Jerome Powell in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, on Friday.
They are worried that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again because of the resilient US economy.
Benchmark Treasury yields climbed to near a 16-year high on the concerns.
Nvidia shares reached a record high of $US481.87 ahead of the chipmaker's profit results.
The S
P 500 fell 0.3 per cent, but the Nasdaq edged higher.
Financial stocks fell after credit ratings agency S
P downgraded the credit ratings of multiple US regional banks.
Coming up today, Woolworths will release its annual profit, which will give us more insight into the impact of the high cost of living on consumers.
Other profit results out today include Domino's Pizza and oil and gas producer Santos.
Join us for all your markets news.
